bibl.title: A model of demographic and economic change in Roman Egypt after the Antonine plague
bibl.note: Argues that in the late 2nd c. A.D. a severe mortality crisis triggered price and wage shocks, and that during the following century the resultant population loss contributed to a decrease in the return on land and to a rise in the real wages of workers. - A model. - Real land rents and land prices. - Nominal commodity prices. - Rural nominal wages. - Rural real wages. - Discussion. - See: Roger S. BAGNALL, The Effects of Plague: Model and Evidence, ibidem, pp. 114-120, 2 tabl.
